repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes #4953.

Before this change the annotations were being treated as
"dataclass-related" annotations, and thus being made "public".

comment_data.body:
I really like conditional expressions for cases like this because they underline the intention to set a variable or attribute, just in different ways depending on a condition.
```suggestion
                scope.is_dataclass = "frozen" if is_frozen else True
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5310,6 +5307,16 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         self.scope = scope = self.entry.type.scope
         if scope is not None:
             scope.directives = env.directives
+            if "dataclasses.dataclass" in env.directives:
+                is_frozen = False
+                dataclass_directives = env.directives["dataclasses.dataclass"]
+                if dataclass_directives:
+                    frozen_directive = dataclass_directives[1].get('frozen', None)
+                    is_frozen = frozen_directive and frozen_directive.is_literal and frozen_directive.value
+                if is_frozen:
+                    scope.is_dataclass = "frozen"
+                else:
+                    scope.is_dataclass = True

comment_data.body: Do we need both conditions? Doesn't `is_dataclass` always imply `is_c_class_scope`? Or are you anticipating some kind of support for Python dataclasses as well?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2160,7 +2155,7 @@ def _analyse_target_declaration(self, env, is_assignment_expression):
             self.entry.known_standard_library_import = ""  # already exists somewhere and so is now ambiguous
         if not self.entry and self.annotation is not None:
             # name : type = ...
-            is_dataclass = 'dataclasses.dataclass' in env.directives
+            is_dataclass = env.is_c_class_scope and env.is_dataclass

comment_data.body:
Hmm, whatever `dataclass_directives[1]` is – probably some kind of dict, but reading code like this suggests that there might be a more descriptive way to represent these "directives".

Note that you don't need to spell out the `None` fallback value for `dict.get()`.
```suggestion
                    frozen_directive = dataclass_directives[1].get('frozen')
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5310,6 +5307,16 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         self.scope = scope = self.entry.type.scope
         if scope is not None:
             scope.directives = env.directives
+            if "dataclasses.dataclass" in env.directives:
+                is_frozen = False
+                dataclass_directives = env.directives["dataclasses.dataclass"]
+                if dataclass_directives:
+                    frozen_directive = dataclass_directives[1].get('frozen', None)

comment_data.body: We probably already know the node's `constant_result` at this point. (You can ask `has_constant_result()`, but there's hopefully some prior piece of validation code that makes sure that we *do* know the constant result of this flag at compile time.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5310,6 +5307,16 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         self.scope = scope = self.entry.type.scope
         if scope is not None:
             scope.directives = env.directives
+            if "dataclasses.dataclass" in env.directives:
+                is_frozen = False
+                dataclass_directives = env.directives["dataclasses.dataclass"]
+                if dataclass_directives:
+                    frozen_directive = dataclass_directives[1].get('frozen', None)
+                    is_frozen = frozen_directive and frozen_directive.is_literal and frozen_directive.value

comment_data.body: It's more that py class scopes won't have the attribute
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2160,7 +2155,7 @@ def _analyse_target_declaration(self, env, is_assignment_expression):
             self.entry.known_standard_library_import = ""  # already exists somewhere and so is now ambiguous
         if not self.entry and self.annotation is not None:
             # name : type = ...
-            is_dataclass = 'dataclasses.dataclass' in env.directives
+            is_dataclass = env.is_c_class_scope and env.is_dataclass

comment_data.body:
Ah, ok, that makes sense.

However, we already have a special `is_closure_class_scope`, so maybe we could call this one `is_c_dataclass_scope` and promote both to `Scope` class attributes? Maybe they are just special enough to make them independent of `is_c_class_scope`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2160,7 +2155,7 @@ def _analyse_target_declaration(self, env, is_assignment_expression):
             self.entry.known_standard_library_import = ""  # already exists somewhere and so is now ambiguous
         if not self.entry and self.annotation is not None:
             # name : type = ...
-            is_dataclass = 'dataclasses.dataclass' in env.directives
+            is_dataclass = env.is_c_class_scope and env.is_dataclass

comment_data.body: I've changed to using `constant_result`. We do currently enforce `is_literal` on these (https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/5ddbe05d419d48161e5938e8de227d41913312ee/Cython/Compiler/Dataclass.py#L181) but I guess `constant_result` is one less thing to change if we change that rule later
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5310,6 +5307,16 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         self.scope = scope = self.entry.type.scope
         if scope is not None:
             scope.directives = env.directives
+            if "dataclasses.dataclass" in env.directives:
+                is_frozen = False
+                dataclass_directives = env.directives["dataclasses.dataclass"]
+                if dataclass_directives:
+                    frozen_directive = dataclass_directives[1].get('frozen', None)
+                    is_frozen = frozen_directive and frozen_directive.is_literal and frozen_directive.value

comment_data.body: (I was referring to the `dataclass_directives` … tuple, maybe? Saying `something[1]` simply doesn't give much information about what we're getting as a result. And I don't mean so much the type of the result as the semantic meaning. Attributes are much clearer since they give a name to the thing that we're looking at. That's why named tuples are better than regular tuples in some cases. Well, and dataclasses.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5310,6 +5307,16 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         self.scope = scope = self.entry.type.scope
         if scope is not None:
             scope.directives = env.directives
+            if "dataclasses.dataclass" in env.directives:
+                is_frozen = False
+                dataclass_directives = env.directives["dataclasses.dataclass"]
+                if dataclass_directives:
+                    frozen_directive = dataclass_directives[1].get('frozen', None)

comment_data.body: Don't think `constant_result` will work. I think directives are taken out of the visited tree before the `ConstantFolding` step so `is_literal` is probably the only way to do it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5310,6 +5307,16 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         self.scope = scope = self.entry.type.scope
         if scope is not None:
             scope.directives = env.directives
+            if "dataclasses.dataclass" in env.directives:
+                is_frozen = False
+                dataclass_directives = env.directives["dataclasses.dataclass"]
+                if dataclass_directives:
+                    frozen_directive = dataclass_directives[1].get('frozen', None)
+                    is_frozen = frozen_directive and frozen_directive.is_literal and frozen_directive.value

comment_data.body:
Ah, thanks for the explanations. Here's a naming proposal then.
```suggestion
                # Retrieve the @dataclass config (args, kwargs), as passed into the decorator.
                dataclass_config = env.directives["dataclasses.dataclass"]
                if dataclass_config:
                    decorator_kwargs = dataclass_config[1]
                    frozen_flag = decorator_kwargs.get('frozen')
                    is_frozen = frozen_flag and frozen_flag.is_literal and frozen_flag.value
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5310,6 +5307,15 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         self.scope = scope = self.entry.type.scope
         if scope is not None:
             scope.directives = env.directives
+            if "dataclasses.dataclass" in env.directives:
+                is_frozen = False
+                # dataclass_directives_args_kwds is either None or a tuple of the args and kwds passed
+                # to the dataclasses.dataclass decorator
+                dataclass_directives_args_kwds = env.directives["dataclasses.dataclass"]
+                if dataclass_directives_args_kwds:
+                    frozen_directive = dataclass_directives_args_kwds[1].get('frozen')
+                    is_frozen = frozen_directive and frozen_directive.is_literal and frozen_directive.value

commit.message:
Treat annotations in functions in dataclasses normally

Fixes #4953.

Before this change the annotations were being treated as
"dataclass-related" annotations, and thus being made "public".
Refactor to drop dataclass directive once it's been applied
Remove comment that relates to changes I didn't make

Apply suggestions from code review

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Treat annotations in functions in dataclasses normally
